words.definition: able to get and retain ideas or information; concerned with acquiring wealth or property
words.example: In an acquisitive society, there is a great deal of emphasis on buying and selling.

words.definition: to claim or take without right
words.example: The ambitious noblemen will arrogate royal privileges to themselves.
The new play's banal dialogue made it seem more like a soap opera than a serious drama.

words.definition: to work on excessively; to thrash soundly
words.example: His tendency to belabor small points often made him miss the big picture.

words.definition: tending to find fault, especially in a petty, nasty, or hairsplitting way; petty, nagging criticism
words.example: The trainee resigned after a week rather than put up with the carping complaints of the sales manager.

words.definition: holding or sticking together; making a logical whole; comprehensible, meaningful
words.example: The physics teacher gave a surprisingly coherent description of quantum mechanics.

words.definition: to change from liquid to solid, thicken; to make inflexible or rigid
words.example: If you do not wash your dishes right away, the food on them will congeal.

words.definition: to imitate with the intent of equaling or surpassing the model
words.example: Most beginning writers try to emulate a great writer and later develop their own individual styles.

words.definition: a formal expression of praise, a lavish tribute
words.example: On Veterans Day, the President delivered a heartfelt encomium to those who died for their country.

words.definition: to avoid, shun, keep away from
words.example: The young athletes promised the coach that they would train vigorously and eschew bad habits.
Bringing up examples from the past is not germane to the present discussion.

words.definition: so great or demanding as not to be satisfied
words.example: People with an insatiable appetite for gossip often do not have compelling stories of their own.
The intransigent attitudes of both sides made negotiation impossible.

words.definition: offensive, hateful; tending to cause ill will or resentment
words.example: The boss made invidious comparisons between the workers.

words.definition: generosity in giving; lavish or bountiful contributions
words.example: The billionaire's largesse helped fund the new hospital wing.

words.definition: a survey made for military purposes; any preliminary examination or exploration
words.example: The scouts conducted reconnaissance before the main attack.

words.definition: to give concrete or substantial form to; to provide with a factual basis
words.example: The lawyer was able to substantiate her client's alibi with witness testimony.

words.definition: habitually silent or quiet, inclined to talk very little
words.example: Abraham Lincoln has the reputation of having a dour and taciturn personality.

words.definition: to stall or act evasively in order to gain time, avoid a confrontation, or postpone a decision
words.example: For most of Shakespeare's greatest tragedy, the protagonist Hamlet chooses to temporize rather than act.

words.definition: capable of being held or defended
words.example: The researchers put forth a tenable theory, but their conclusions would be reviewed carefully by others.

words.definition: to approach and speak to first; to confront in a challenging or aggressive way
words.example: The nobleman was accosted by beggars on his way to the castle.

words.definition: a comment indicating strong criticism or disapproval
words.example: The inexperienced filmmaker was disheartened by the animadversion of the film critic.

words.definition: desirous of something to the point of greed; intensely eager
words.example: Most writers are also avid readers who have loved books since childhood.

words.definition: having a salty taste and unpleasant to drink
words.example: The shipwrecked passengers adrift on the lifeboat became ill after drinking brackish water.

words.definition: swiftness, rapidity of motion or action
words.example: Although the heavy snowfall was not expected, the highway department responded with surprising celerity.

words.definition: straying or wandering from a straight or direct course; done or acting in a shifty or underhanded way
words.example: The interrogator used devious methods to try to get the suspect to incriminate himself.

words.definition: in chess, an opening move that involves risk or sacrifice of a minor piece in order to gain a later advantage; any opening move of this type
words.example: Asking an interesting stranger about his or her job is a popular party gambit.

words.definition: of or relating to the halcyon; calm, peaceful; happy, golden; prosperous, affluent
words.example: The woman often spoke of the halcyon days of her childhood.

words.definition: pertaining to actors and their techniques; theatrical, artificial; melodramatic
words.example: Upon receiving his award, the young actor gave a histrionic speech.

words.definition: deliberately setting or causing fires; designed to start fires; tending to stir up strife or rebellion
words.example: The politician's incendiary remarks sparked protests in the streets.

words.definition: a whirlpool of great size and violence; a situation resembling a whirlpool in violence and destruction
words.example: Many innocent people caught in the maelstrom of the revolution lost their lives and property.

words.definition: nearsighted; lacking a broad, realistic view of a situation; lacking foresight or discernment
words.example: The myopic foreign policy of the last administration has led to serious problems with our allies.

words.definition: open, not hidden, expressed or revealed in a way that is easily recognized
words.example: In order for Congress to declare war, the President must demonstrate an overt threat.

words.definition: tending to make worse; expressing disapproval or disparagement, derogatory, deprecatory, belittling
words.example: The lawyer was accused of making a pejorative remark when referring to the defendant's background.

words.definition: the state of being proper, appropriateness; standards of what is proper or socially acceptable
words.example: The social worker questioned the propriety of the police's request to see confidential records.

words.definition: improper or disrespectful treatment of something held sacred
words.example: The anthropologist was accused of committing a sacrilege when she disturbed an ancient burial ground.

words.definition: without delay or formality; briefly, concisely
words.example: As soon as there was evidence of criminal wrongdoing, the official was summarily ousted from his post.

words.definition: asking humbly and earnestly; one who makes a request humbly and earnestly, a petitioner, suitor
words.example: Stranded in the deserted city of Moscow, Napoleon had to turn to the Czar not as a conqueror but as a suppliant.

words.definition: an object that serves as a charm or is believed to confer magical powers, an amulet, fetish
words.example: Most people do not believe that rabbit's feet and other talismans actually bring good luck.

words.definition: to move in waves or with a wavelike motion; to have a wavelike appearance or form
words.example: The baseball fans began to undulate as they cheered, so that they appeared to move in a wave.

words.definition: to pronounce distinctly; to express well in words; to connect by a joint or joints; expressed clearly and forcefully; able to employ language clearly and forcefully; jointed
words.example: Few people can articulate their emotions during times of stress.

words.definition: to romp or prance around exuberantly; to make merry
words.example: The actors in the musical cavort on stage.
The government and the public failed to give credence to the reports of an impending water shortage.

words.definition: to condemn, express strong disapproval; to officially depreciate
words.example: Every arm of government and every educational institution should decry bigotry in all its forms.

words.definition: to disguise or conceal, deliberately give a false impression
words.example: The young man was unable to dissemble his feelings and admitted to having committed the crime.

words.definition: very much agitated or upset as a result of emotion or mental conflict
words.example: The workforce became distraught in the wake of the 1929 stock market crash.

words.definition: a formal statement of commendation; high praise
words.example: The best friend and longtime law partner of the deceased delivered the eulogy at the funeral.

words.definition: to display clearly, to make evident, to provoke
words.example: The crowd did not evince any signs of panic but moved in an orderly fashion to the nearest exits.

words.definition: to remove from a grave; to bring to light
words.example: Suspecting foul play, the coroner issued an order to exhume the body immediately.

words.definition: lacking in spirit and strength; ineffective, weak; irresponsible, unreliable
words.example: Although a feckless youth, he eventually matured into a hard-working and responsible citizen.

words.definition: dark and gloomy; unclear, confused; lacking in clarity and precision
words.example: The murky waters of the swamp made it difficult to see the bottom.

words.definition: wicked, depraved, devoid of moral standards
words.example: Brutus had nefarious motives when he agreed to participate in the plot against Caesar.

words.definition: stimulating to the taste or mind; spicy, pungent; lively, vivacious; appealingly provocative
words.example: The chef's piquant sauce added excitement to the otherwise bland dish.

words.definition: developed or created at the very beginning; going back to the most ancient times or earliest stage; fundamental, basic
words.example: Scientists study primordial elements to understand the formation of the universe.

words.definition: nearness in place or time; kinship
words.example: The propinquity of the two houses made it easy for the neighbors to visit.

words.definition: not usual or expected; not in character
words.example: The usually quiet student showed unwonted enthusiasm during the debate.

words.definition: founded upon or involving a visionary view of an ideal world; impractical
words.example: The candidate's utopian promises seemed too good to be true.

words.definition: language that is wordy and generally meaningless; wordiness
words.example: The politician's speech was full of verbiage but lacking in substance.

words.definition: green in tint or color; immature in experience or judgment
words.example: The verdant meadow was a beautiful sight in spring.

words.definition: having a gelatinous or sticky quality; thick, syrupy
words.example: The viscous honey slowly dripped from the spoon.

words.definition: the wasting away of a body organ or tissue; any progressive decline or failure; to waste away
words.example: Without regular exercise, muscles will atrophy.

words.definition: a fortified place, stronghold; a strong position or supporter
words.example: The university was considered a bastion of political conservatism.

words.definition: a state of agreement, harmony, unanimity; a treaty, pact, covenant
words.example: The two nations signed a concord to end the long-standing conflict.

words.definition: to bring to a completion, accomplish, achieve, perfect; supremely skilled and accomplished; complete or perfect in every respect
words.example: She is a consummate professional who handles every situation with grace.

words.definition: to deny responsibility for or connection with; to disclaim, disown
words.example: The candidate was forced to disavow the controversial statements made by his supporters.

words.definition: to remove objectionable passages or words from a written text; to cleanse, purify
words.example: The editor chose to expurgate the controversial sections from the manuscript.

words.definition: an armored or protective glove; a challenge; two lines of men armed with weapons
words.example: The new employee had to run the gauntlet of office politics.

words.definition: based on an assumption or guess; used as a provisional or tentative idea to guide investigation
words.example: The professor posed a hypothetical question to stimulate discussion.

words.definition: mean, low, base; not worthy of honor or respect; not noble in character; of humble origin or social status
words.example: It was ignoble of him to betray his friend's trust.

words.definition: to call into question; to attack as false or questionable
words.example: The defense attorney tried to impugn the credibility of the witness.
They will incarcerate the criminal in the state penitentiary.

words.definition: obligatory, required; one who holds a specific office at the time spoken of
words.example: It is incumbent upon citizens to vote in elections.
His jocular remarks lightened the mood of the serious meeting.
The suggestion that we solve the budget crisis by printing more money is ludicrous.

words.definition: biting or caustic in thought, manner, or style; sharply or harshly critical
words.example: The critic's mordant review destroyed the actor's confidence.

words.definition: to arouse displeasure, impatience, or anger; to vex or irritate; a prickly or stinging plant
words.example: His constant interruptions began to nettle the speaker.

words.definition: consisting of or measured in money; of or related to money
words.example: The company faced serious pecuniary difficulties during the recession.
The pusillanimous general refused to lead his troops into battle.
The tired toddlers were recumbent on the couch after playing all afternoon in the yard.
words.definition: in a reclining position, lying down, in the posture of one sleeping or resting

words.example: The defense attorney used a clever stratagem to curry sympathy for her client.
words.definition: a scheme to outwit or deceive an opponent or to gain an end
sharpness, particularly of the mind or senses
to portray, sketch, or describe in accurate and vivid detail; to represent pictorially
marked by evil and corruption; devoid of moral principles
to weaken or lessen the mental, moral, or physical vigor of; to enfeeble or hamstring
intended for or understood by only a select few; private or secret
fruitful in offspring or vegetation; intellectually productive
an arbitrary order or decree; a command or act of will or consciousness
a fabrication of the mind; an arbitrary notion
to acquire as the result of effort; to gather and store away for future use
to set apart as holy or sacred; to sanctify or consecrate; to honor greatly or revere
a peculiarity that serves to distinguish or identify
earthly, worldly, relating to practical and material affairs; concerned with what is ordinary
a subtle or slight variation (as in color, meaning, or quality); a delicate gradation or shade of difference
according to reputation or general belief; having widespread acceptance and good reputation; alleged
reasoning that seems plausible but is actually unsound; a fallacy
degraded; base, contemptible; cringing, servile; complete and unrelieved
one who believes that nothing can be known about God; a skeptic; without faith, skeptical
involvement in wrongdoing; the state of being an accomplice
someone or something that is abandoned or neglected; left abandoned; neglectful of duty
a bitter and prolonged verbal attack
a crude image of a despised person
the state or quality of being just, fair, or impartial; fair and equal treatment; something that is fair; the money value of a property above and beyond any mortgage
silly; empty of meaning or value
the act of accusing; a formal accusation
certain; not to be doubted or denied
open to discussion and debate; unresolved; to bring up for discussion; a hypothetical law case argued by students
a principal idea, feature, theme, or element; a repeated or dominant figure in a design
complete in all aspects or essentials; absolute; attended by all qualified members
a watch kept over a person; careful, close, and disciplined observation
pertaining to or characteristic of forests; living or located in a forest; wooded, woody
easily irritated; characterized by impatience and exasperation
a grotesque or grossly inferior imitation; a disguise, especially the clothing of the opposite sex; to ridicule by imitating in a broad or burlesque fashion
to calm or pacify, set to rest; to lessen or relieve
beastlike; beastly, brutal; subhuman in intelligence and sensibility
festive, sociable, having fun together, genial
a circle of acquaintances; a close-knit, often exclusive, group of people with a common interest
a person or thing closely resembling or corresponding to another; a complement
to object or take exception to; an objection
to decorate, adorn, touch up; to improve by adding details
lasting only a short time; short-lived
appropriate, apt, well chosen; marked by well-being or good fortune; happy
done slyly or stealthily; sneaky, secret, shifty; stolen
glaring; tastelessly showy or overdecorated in a vulgar or offensive way
misleading, deceptive; lacking in or not based on reality
far too great; exceeding reasonable limits; excessive
to cast overboard; get rid of as unnecessary or burdensome
a person who hates or despises people
very persistent; holding firmly to a course of action or set of beliefs; hard to get rid of
of little value or importance; paltry, measly; concerned with trifling matters; small-minded
to assert without proof or confirmation
words.example: The newspaper tabloid alleged that the movie star and the director were having creative differences.
In Shakespeare's tragedy the audience sees clearly that Iago is an arrant scoundrel.
I enjoy the delightful badinage between old Hollywood film stars.

words.definition: to overcome the distrust of, win over; to appease, pacify; to reconcile
words.example: Because of the weakness of our army, we had to try to conciliate the enemy.

words.definition: to cancel or reverse one order or command with another that is contrary to the first
words.example: Today's directive clearly countermands all previous fire-exit instructions.

words.definition: one of a series of grades in an organization or field of activity; an organized military unit; a steplike formation or arrangement
words.example: He began in the lower echelons of government service but rose quickly.

words.definition: to make more violent, severe, bitter, or painful
words.example: Shouting and name-calling will only exacerbate any quarrel.

words.definition: stupid or foolish in a self-satisfied way
words.example: The columnist quoted several of the candidate's more fatuous remarks.
The jury believed the prosecution presented irrefutable evidence of guilt.

words.definition: a massive and inescapable force or object that crushes whatever is in its path
words.example: The survivors would never forget the juggernaut of war.
The team's late-inning performance was lackadaisical because they were so far ahead.

words.definition: a repetitive chant; a long list; a prayer with repeated responses
words.example: Whenever she talked about her childhood, she recited a litany of grievances.

words.definition: grisly, gruesome; horrible, distressing; having death as a subject
words.example: Horror films often rely on macabre imagery to draw audiences.
The campaign was marred by a paucity of original ideas.

words.definition: to indicate beforehand that something is about to happen; to give advance warning of
words.example: In Shakespeare's plays, strange events often portend disaster.

words.definition: to tear down, destroy completely; to cut or scrape off
words.example: The town razed the old schoolhouse to build a modern complex.

words.definition: to withdraw a statement or belief previously committed to; retract
words.example: On the stand, the defendant recanted her earlier admissions.

words.definition: to soak thoroughly; fill to capacity; to satisfy fully
words.example: The sponge was saturated with water but did not drip.

words.definition: of a gloomy or surly disposition; cold or sluggish in mood
words.example: Scrooge begins the story with a saturnine personality.

words.definition: to cast off or discard; to get rid of something objectionable; to plod through as if through mud; a mire; a state of depression
words.example: Many people resolve to slough off bad habits at the start of a new year.
